data.prompt:
Generate me a prompt with this twitter post in mind. Modify it for an advertisement for a Japanese language learning app called Chatomo where you learn to speak Japanese through conversation with an AI language partner of your choosing or that you made. Ensure we involve some Japanese language in the mix to teach viewers. Give the character an energetic and forward personality that garners attention from their voice and actions.

This is going to be a step by step breakdown on how to make longform AI videos that LOOK and SOUND realistic…
So you can push out crazy amounts of realistic ads & content for your business.
I'd highly recommend reading this till the end because where this article gets really valuable is how we ensure consistent pacing & natural audio across the entire video… which to me is the biggest telltale of whether a video is AI or not.
(Note: this is focused on making talking head/UGC type videos)
Step 1: Make The Base Image
The base image includes two things:
The character that will be speaking in the video
The setting of the video
To do this we'll be using Nano Banana Pro. You can access it pretty cheap through tools like Higgsfield or Freepik.
Now here's the thing most people get wrong…
The issue with a lot of AI videos is they look too perfect. Too clean. They all have like mannequin-look.
Which makes it super obvious it's AI.
So when you're prompting for your base image… yes you want to describe the character & setting… but it's just as important to include imperfections.
I'm talking micro-pores, natural oils, fine lines… the shit people actually have on their skin.
And make sure there's no studio lighting. We don't want this looking too professional. We want it to feel like someone just hit record on their phone.
Here's an example prompt I use:
A vertical 9:16 UGC-style video frame captured on an iPhone 11 resting on a tripod. The composition is a medium-wide portrait, framed at true eye-level with a slightly forward-leaning posture for conversational authority. A man in his early 40s with a youthful, Mediterranean complexion—olive-toned skin, deep-set dark brown eyes beneath strong, naturally thick brows, and a prominent aquiline nose with a subtle Roman bridge. His jawline is angular and well-defined, dusted with 2-day dark stubble that thickens slightly at the chin. Dark, almost black hair is thick and slightly tousled, with textured fringe sweeping across his forehead in casual disarray. Expression is warm and engaged—a genuine, broad smile revealing straight teeth with natural slight imperfections, a hint of gum line visible, laugh lines crinkling at the outer corners of his eyes. He wears a fitted black henley, collar slightly askew. Skin texture shows visible pores across the T-zone, faint smile lines deepened by the expression, and natural oils catching light on the forehead and nose.

In the immediate foreground: his hands rest naturally on the oak desk surface, fingers relaxed and slightly interlaced, visible veins and knuckle texture catching the light, a simple watch on his left wrist. Nearby sits a half-empty water bottle, wireless earbuds case, and a notebook with a pen—NOT heavily blurred, just a mild iPhone-style computational depth gradient suggesting nearness. The hands and forearms occupy the lower third of the frame naturally.

Camera behavior uses the native iPhone 11 lens (26mm equivalent): slightly wide, honest perspective, mild barrel softness at edges, minimal compression. The background remains mostly sharp: a dark wood bookcase filled with hardcovers and a few framed photos is clearly readable to the left; a black Peloton bike with its red accent screen sits in the corner to the right, identifiable down to the handlebar grips. Only tiny pockets of neural blur appear around hair edges and the watch face—true iPhone depth-map artifacts.
Lighting is "Available Light": a mix of cool overcast daylight filtering through a large window from the left and warm tungsten from a brass desk lamp on the right, creating imperfect balance and natural falloff. Shadows are soft but asymmetric, with slight warmth pooling under the cheekbones and cooler tones washing across the white wall behind the bookcase. ISO noise from 500–900 sits naturally in midtones, producing sensor grain and mild vignetting (12% falloff).
Skin is rendered with natural texture: visible micro pores across the nose and cheeks, faint peach fuzz catching sidelight along the jawline, subtle stubble shadow density variation, and soft lip line diffusion. Natural oils break through on the forehead and nose bridge; no foundation, no filter. Faint dark circles sit under the eyes—realistic, lived-in. Teeth show natural enamel texture with minor tonal variation, not bleached-white perfection.

Reality details: gentle 35mm film grain, light fingerprint smudge on lens glass, tiny dust haze in the air, and minimal chromatic aberration around high-contrast edges where the black shirt meets the bright wall. No cinematic bloom, no studio finish. The entire image should feel candid, trustworthy, conversational, and truly user-generated—like a high-performing coaching or sales UGC testimonial.

Styling Overlay: raw UGC realism, available indoor light, mixed color temperature, minimal depth blur, slight lens smudge, visible ISO noise, no cinematic polish, emphasis on authenticity and true iPhone capture.
Once you've generated the image with Nano Banana Pro… throw it through Enhancor AI. It's an upscaling tool that adds even more realistic texture to the character.
Step 2: Generate The Video
At this point you should have your script & your base image ready.
Now we generate the actual video.
I personally like Kling 2.6 the most… but Veo 3.1 is really good for this too.
But here's the problem…
If you have a script that's 60+ seconds long… video generation models like Kling & Veo only allow 10 seconds per generation.
And yeah… we made a base image we can use as a reference frame to keep character consistency across all the clips.
But it's not that simple.
You can't just generate a bunch of clips & splice them together.
Because the pacing will be different across all of them.
The Pacing Problem (And How To Fix It)
The thing I hate about most AI generated videos is the pacing of the character just often feels too robotic...
And it's tough.
Because if you put too little of a script in a single video generation call… the character speaks too slow. Even if you tell it to speed up… it messes up half the time.
If you put too much of the script… the character speaks way too fast.
You have to find the sweet spot.
And what I've found to be the perfect pacing is 55-60 syllables per generation call.
So what you do is break your script into chunks of 55-60 syllables each.
But don't cut the script off mid-sentence... you want to break it by full sentences or else it'll sound unnatural af. 
And if you get to a point where you're at like 40 syllables & the next sentence would push you to 75… just add a short filler sentence to get you to 60.
This way every single clip has the same pacing. And when you splice them all together the character sounds consistent throughout the whole video.
Making The Character Feel Real
Now let's talk about making the character actually feel human.
The problem with most AI talking head videos is the character is way too still.
Think about when you record a selfie video or even something on your webcam…
There's natural spinal movement. Micro sways. Side to side. Back & forth. Shit you don't even notice you're doing.
Your hands move. Your head moves. Not huge exaggerated movements… but subtle shifts while staying in roughly the same resting position.
That's what makes it feel real.
So in your video generation prompt… you need to include this stuff.
Here's an example prompt I use that you can model off of:
Hand "Home Base" Protocol: Hands default to a relaxed but alive position (Active Idle). Fingers shift, thumbs rub, or wrists rotate slightly while anchored. Gestures occur only to emphasize key moments.

[Action]: [0.0s-0.5s] [Simultaneous Cluster: Sharp Inhale + Eyes lock instantly to lens + Head is still (Pre-roll Buffer)]

[0.5s-3.0s] [Simultaneous Cluster: [Hands in Active Idle (fingers interlocked, tight grip, thumbs pressing down)] + [Head tilts slightly right] + [Brows furrow slightly in seriousness]]

[3.0s-6.0s] [Simultaneous Cluster: [Hands break clasp for a quick, contained open-palm rotation then return to base] + [Head drifts forward] + [Natural blink]]

[6.0s-8.0s] [Simultaneous Cluster: [Hands return to Active Idle (loose clasp, thumbs tapping)] + [Head nods encouragingly] + [Cheeks lift in a natural smile]]

[8.0s-10.0s] [Simultaneous Cluster: [Hands anchored (wrist shifts position)] + [Chin lifts in a quick, final nod] + [Natural blink]]

[Script & Tonality]: (Tone: Urgent, Scarcity-driven, Serious) "We only have 20 spots available because of our trainer capacity, and they fill up extremely fast." (Tone: Directive, Warm, Expectant) "So click the button below, and I can't wait to see you in the gym." (Tone: Rapid, Final, Clean) "and that is it for today."

[Mood and Audio Pacing]: Rapid fire delivery, high energy, viral UGC style, confident, speaks fast the pacing [audio] should be at 2x speed
Notice here in the prompt how I define the natural, subtle actions that the character should do at specific intervals throughout the video. 
Post-Production
At this point you've got all your clips generated.
Now you wanna oad them into CapCut, put them all together and splice out any filler sentences or awkward pauses so it flows smoothly.
Now there's two things I always do in post…
Fixing The Voice
To me the biggest telltale with AI is how shitty the voices sound.
Yeah people say use ElevenLab… but 11Labs sounds too studio-like.
Remember just like with the images & videos… we don't want it sounding too nice. Because when you actually record yourself it's never that polished.
Option 1: Adobe Podcast
This is the bare minimum. It's an audio cleaning tool & it does wonders.
If you've ever listened to raw Sora audio on mobile… it sounds terrible. But throw it through Adobe Podcast & it cleans that shit up so well it's insane.
It's super cheap and easy. Like I would do this at the absolute bare minimum.
Option 2: Resemble AI (shoutout @Mho_23 for posting about this one)
This is a voice changer tool similar to Eleven Labs but it sounds way more natural in my opinion.
If you want to actually swap out the voice & make it sound legit… Resemble AI is what I'd recommend.
Covering The Jump Cuts
When you splice all these clips together you're going to have natural jump cuts. That's just how it is when you're stitching 8-10 second clips together.
The fix is simply is just use B-roll or animations over it
Once you have that in place & the pacing is smooth & the audio sounds legit…
The videos look so good & feel so realistic it's so sick.
If you want more AI sauce, sign up for my newsletter: https://tyler-vu.kit.com/main
Side note there is also an AI tool called infinitetalk that people are using to make long form talking head AI videos
My only gripe against it is the pacing I don't have as much control over it as I do with the syllable method bc there's no timer with that tool at least of right now where I can say give me a 60s video... 
It's more so like hey here's the image and the prompt and they just charge you credits by how long the video takes.

data.inputContext:
Give me back only the dialogue and nothing else. The purpose of this is to create a chunked dialogue. So no directions, no explaining the style, no queues or anything like that. Just straight up dialogue to be chunked out. Do not give me a response explaining anything, simple give me the words that are meant to be spoken

IMPORTANT DIALOGUE RULES:
  - DO NOT EXCEED 36 syllables per chunk
  - GIVE EXACTLY 5 chunks with a clear beginning video dialogue that does not trigger a transition for the first chunk and clear ending video dialogue telling the user to download the app for the last chunk
  - Mention the app name vs using a textbook or flashcard style app like DuoLingo at the second chunk  
- Never use phrases that sound like segment beginnings
- Never use phrases that sound like segment endings
- Write as if the speaker is mid-conversation, not starting or ending a lesson
- Avoid instructional/teacher language - sound like a friend sharing, not a teacher lecturing
- No call-to-action phrases within the dialogue (save those for captions/overlays or the last chunk)
- Each sentence should flow naturally into the next without feeling like a "moment" or "beat"

  BAD examples (trigger transitions):
  - "Let's learn a useful phrase"
  - "Repeat it with me"
  - "Now here's the important part"
  - "And that's how you do it"

  GOOD examples (continuous speech):
  - "A useful phrase is..."
  - "Try saying it: ..."
  - "The interesting thing is..."
  - "Which brings us to..."

The purpose is to generate a prompt that won't signal a video transition of any kind as this is a talking head video and we want it to be a single segment.

Make it fun and powerful, don't be shy about being silly or energetic.

Give me back only the dialogue and nothing else. The purpose of this is to create a chunked dialogue for video generation.

  CRITICAL: Avoid any phrases that sound like beginnings or endings of segments. No "Let's learn", "Repeat after me", "That's all for now", etc. Write as continuous mid-conversation speech that flows naturally. Each chunk should feel like it could be in the middle of a longer conversation, never a clear intro or outro.

No directions, no style explanations, no stage queues. Just the spoken words, written to flow continuously without natural "break points" that video AI might interpret as transitions.
data.outputText:
Honestly, my Japanese was so stiff before, but now I’m actually talking back and it feels meccha yabai!

I ditched those boring flashcards and apps like Duolingo for Chatomo because I can just make my own crazy AI friends.

Like, I built this cool punk girl who teaches me slang, so I’m finally sounding way more natural and pera-pera.

It is wild how fast you pick up words when you are actually laughing and joking around in a real conversation.

You honestly have to try this if you want to speak for real, so go download Chatomo and start talking today.

data.inputScript:
Honestly, my Japanese was so stiff before, but now I’m actually talking back and it feels meccha yabai!

I ditched those boring flashcards and apps like Duolingo for Chatomo because I can just make my own crazy AI friends.

Like, I built this cool punk girl who teaches me slang, so I’m finally sounding way more natural and pera-pera.

It is wild how fast you pick up words when you are actually laughing and joking around in a real conversation.

You honestly have to try this if you want to speak for real, so go download Chatomo and start talking today.
outputChunks: Dialogue: Honestly, my Japanese was so stiff before, but now I’m actually talking back and it feels meccha yabai!
Dialogue: I ditched those boring flashcards and apps like Duolingo for Chatomo because I can just make my own crazy AI friends.
Dialogue: Like, I built this cool punk girl who teaches me slang, so I’m finally sounding way more natural and pera-pera.
Dialogue: It is wild how fast you pick up words when you are actually laughing and joking around in a real conversation.
Dialogue: You honestly have to try this if you want to speak for real, so go download Chatomo and start talking today.

data.inputContext:
A high-definition, vertical 9:16 talking head video captured from the perspective of someone holding a smartphone. The camera is completely static for a single, continuous shot with no transitions, no cuts, and no scene changes. The framing remains perfectly locked throughout the entire duration; there is no zooming, no shifting in aspect ratio, and no black borders. The composition of the first frame is identical to the last frame.

The subject is a young woman with long, straight blonde hair tucked behind her ears, sitting at a low wooden table on a traditional Japanese veranda. She has a bright, energetic, and fun personality. The lighting is soft and natural, highlighting her realistic skin texture, including fine pores and subtle natural blemishes. She is wearing a traditional Japanese samue with large geometric blocks of slate blue and beige. 

As she speaks, she is highly animated and expressive, using her hands to gesture enthusiastically. Her movements are fluid and natural. Between every spoken sentence, she takes a deliberate, brief pause, maintaining a cheerful and engaging presence. She is looking directly into the camera lens as if chatting with a friend. 

The foreground features a weathered wooden table holding sheets of calligraphy paper with black ink characters, a bamboo brush resting on a holder, and an ink stone. The background is a lush, vibrant green Japanese moss garden with slender trees and a traditional stone lantern, all softly out of focus to create depth. The audio consists only of her voice and natural background sounds, such as the distant rustle of leaves and birdsong. The video concludes with her looking directly into the camera with a warm, energetic smile.

Shadows are soft but asymmetric, with slight warmth pooling under the cheekbones and cooler tones washing across the white wall behind the bookcase. ISO noise from 500–900 sits naturally in midtones, producing sensor grain and mild vignetting (12% falloff).
Skin is rendered with natural texture: visible micro pores across the nose and cheeks, faint peach fuzz catching sidelight along the jawline, subtle stubble shadow density variation, and soft lip line diffusion. Natural oils break through on the forehead and nose bridge; no foundation, no filter. Faint dark circles sit under the eyes—realistic, lived-in. Teeth show natural enamel texture with minor tonal variation, not bleached-white perfection.

Reality details: gentle 35mm film grain, light fingerprint smudge on lens glass, tiny dust haze in the air, and minimal chromatic aberration around high-contrast edges where the black shirt meets the bright wall. No cinematic bloom, no studio finish. The entire image should feel candid, trustworthy, conversational, and truly user-generated—like a high-performing coaching or sales UGC testimonial.

Styling Overlay: raw UGC realism, available indoor light, mixed color temperature, minimal depth blur, slight lens smudge, visible ISO noise, no cinematic polish, emphasis on authenticity and true iPhone capture.
Once you've generated the image with Nano Banana Pro… throw it through Enhancor AI. It's an upscaling tool that adds even more realistic texture to the character.
Step 2: Generate The Video
At this point you should have your script & your base image ready.
Now we generate the actual video.
I personally like Kling 2.6 the most… but Veo 3.1 is really good for this too.
But here's the problem…
If you have a script that's 60+ seconds long… video generation models like Kling & Veo only allow 10 seconds per generation.
And yeah… we made a base image we can use as a reference frame to keep character consistency across all the clips.
But it's not that simple.
You can't just generate a bunch of clips & splice them together.
Because the pacing will be different across all of them.
The Pacing Problem (And How To Fix It)
The thing I hate about most AI generated videos is the pacing of the character just often feels too robotic...
And it's tough.
Because if you put too little of a script in a single video generation call… the character speaks too slow. Even if you tell it to speed up… it messes up half the time.
If you put too much of the script… the character speaks way too fast.
You have to find the sweet spot.
And what I've found to be the perfect pacing is 55-60 syllables per generation call.
So what you do is break your script into chunks of 55-60 syllables each.
But don't cut the script off mid-sentence... you want to break it by full sentences or else it'll sound unnatural af. 
And if you get to a point where you're at like 40 syllables & the next sentence would push you to 75… just add a short filler sentence to get you to 60.
This way every single clip has the same pacing. And when you splice them all together the character sounds consistent throughout the whole video.
Making The Character Feel Real
Now let's talk about making the character actually feel human.
The problem with most AI talking head videos is the character is way too still.
Think about when you record a selfie video or even something on your webcam…
There's natural spinal movement. Micro sways. Side to side. Back & forth. Shit you don't even notice you're doing.
Your hands move. Your head moves. Not huge exaggerated movements… but subtle shifts while staying in roughly the same resting position.
That's what makes it feel real.
So in your video generation prompt… you need to include this stuff.
Here's an example prompt I use that you can model off of:
Hand "Home Base" Protocol: Hands default to a relaxed but alive position (Active Idle). Fingers shift, thumbs rub, or wrists rotate slightly while anchored. Gestures occur only to emphasize key moments.

[Action]: [0.0s-0.5s] [Simultaneous Cluster: Sharp Inhale + Eyes lock instantly to lens + Head is still (Pre-roll Buffer)]

[0.5s-3.0s] [Simultaneous Cluster: [Hands in Active Idle (fingers interlocked, tight grip, thumbs pressing down)] + [Head tilts slightly right] + [Brows furrow slightly in seriousness]]

[3.0s-6.0s] [Simultaneous Cluster: [Hands break clasp for a quick, contained open-palm rotation then return to base] + [Head drifts forward] + [Natural blink]]

[6.0s-8.0s] [Simultaneous Cluster: [Hands return to Active Idle (loose clasp, thumbs tapping)] + [Head nods encouragingly] + [Cheeks lift in a natural smile]]

[8.0s-10.0s] [Simultaneous Cluster: [Hands anchored (wrist shifts position)] + [Chin lifts in a quick, final nod] + [Natural blink]]

[Script & Tonality]: (Tone: Urgent, Scarcity-driven, Serious) "We only have 20 spots available because of our trainer capacity, and they fill up extremely fast." (Tone: Directive, Warm, Expectant) "So click the button below, and I can't wait to see you in the gym." (Tone: Rapid, Final, Clean) "and that is it for today."

[Mood and Audio Pacing]: Rapid fire delivery, high energy, viral UGC style, confident, speaks fast the pacing [audio] should be at 2x speed
Notice here in the prompt how I define the natural, subtle actions that the character should do at specific intervals throughout the video. 
Post-Production
At this point you've got all your clips generated.
Now you wanna oad them into CapCut, put them all together and splice out any filler sentences or awkward pauses so it flows smoothly.
Now there's two things I always do in post…
Fixing The Voice
To me the biggest telltale with AI is how shitty the voices sound.
Yeah people say use ElevenLab… but 11Labs sounds too studio-like.
Remember just like with the images & videos… we don't want it sounding too nice. Because when you actually record yourself it's never that polished.
Option 1: Adobe Podcast
This is the bare minimum. It's an audio cleaning tool & it does wonders.
If you've ever listened to raw Sora audio on mobile… it sounds terrible. But throw it through Adobe Podcast & it cleans that shit up so well it's insane.
It's super cheap and easy. Like I would do this at the absolute bare minimum.
Option 2: Resemble AI (shoutout @Mho_23 for posting about this one)
This is a voice changer tool similar to Eleven Labs but it sounds way more natural in my opinion.
If you want to actually swap out the voice & make it sound legit… Resemble AI is what I'd recommend.
Covering The Jump Cuts
When you splice all these clips together you're going to have natural jump cuts. That's just how it is when you're stitching 8-10 second clips together.
The fix is simply is just use B-roll or animations over it
Once you have that in place & the pacing is smooth & the audio sounds legit…
The videos look so good & feel so realistic it's so sick.
If you want more AI sauce, sign up for my newsletter: https://tyler-vu.kit.com/main
Side note there is also an AI tool called infinitetalk that people are using to make long form talking head AI videos
My only gripe against it is the pacing I don't have as much control over it as I do with the syllable method bc there's no timer with that tool at least of right now where I can say give me a 60s video... 
It's more so like hey here's the image and the prompt and they just charge you credits by how long the video takes.
data.inputContext: Give me back only the  directions, explaining the style, queues and every thing like that.
inputImages: data too long so I removed it
data.outputText:
### **AI Video Generation Prompt: Chatomo "Real-Talk" UGC Advertisement**

**Base Image Description (The "Realism" Layer):**
A vertical 9:16 UGC-style frame captured on an iPhone 11. The composition is a medium-close portrait of a woman in her late 20s with blonde hair, sitting at a low wooden table on a traditional Japanese *engawa* (porch). She is wearing a blue and tan patterned yukata. Her skin texture is hyper-realistic: visible micro-pores on the nose, natural oils on the forehead, and slight "laugh lines" around the eyes. No studio lighting; the scene is lit by natural overcast daylight from the garden and soft shadows from the wooden pillars. In the foreground, an iPhone rests on the table showing the **Chatomo** app interface, next to a calligraphy brush and ink stone. The background shows a lush, slightly out-of-focus moss garden with a stone lantern. Minimal depth blur, slight lens smudge, and natural ISO grain to ensure it looks like a phone recording, not a render.

---

**Hand "Home Base" Protocol:**
Hands begin resting near the calligraphy paper. As she speaks, one hand moves to gesture toward the phone (the Chatomo app), while the other performs "Active Idle" (fingers twitching slightly or resting on the table edge). Gestures are sharp and energetic to match the "forward" personality.

---

**Action & Movement Cues (0.0s - 10.0s):**

*   **[0.0s-0.5s]** [Simultaneous Cluster: Sharp, excited inhale + Wide-eyed "hook" expression + Head leans 10% closer to the lens.]
*   **[0.5s-3.5s]** [Simultaneous Cluster: Left hand points energetically toward the phone on the table + Rapid head nod + Brows lift in an "Aha!" expression.]
*   **[3.5s-6.5s]** [Simultaneous Cluster: Hands move into a "counting" gesture (holding up fingers) + Torso sways slightly side-to-side (natural spinal movement) + Frequent natural blinks.]
*   **[6.5s-8.5s]** [Simultaneous Cluster: Hands return to table ("Home Base") + A broad, genuine smile showing natural teeth + Head tilts 15 degrees to the right in a friendly, inviting manner.]
*   **[8.5s-10.0s]** [Simultaneous Cluster: Quick "peace sign" or wave gesture + Eyes lock back to lens + Final sharp nod of authority.]

---

**Script & Tonality (55-60 Syllable Chunk):**

**Tone:** High-energy, infectious, rapid-fire, and encouraging.
**Language:** Mix of English and Japanese (Teaching Moment).

*(Script Chunking for Pacing):*
"Stop scrolling! Want to speak Japanese? Say: **'Nihongo ga suki desu!'** That means 'I love Japanese!' I learned that in two minutes on **Chatomo**. You literally build your own AI partner to talk to. It’s not a bot, it’s a vibe. Download Chatomo now and let’s speak! **Ganbatte!**"

---

**Mood and Audio Pacing:**
*   **Pacing:** Rapid-fire delivery, viral UGC style. Audio should be processed to sound like a high-quality phone microphone (use Adobe Podcast/Resemble AI to remove "studio" polish).
*   **Energy:** 1.2x speed tonality. The voice should sound like a friend who is genuinely obsessed with the app.
*   **Reality Details:** Include a subtle "thud" sound when her hand hits the table and the faint sound of wind/birds from the Japanese garden in the background to sell the environment.

---

**Post-Production Style Overlay:**
*   **Visuals:** Raw UGC realism, available indoor/outdoor mixed light, slight lens flare from the garden.
*   **Text Overlays:** Use "TikTok style" captions that pop up word-by-word in sync with the rapid-fire delivery. Highlight the Japanese words (**Nihongo / Ganbatte**) in a different color.

data.prompt: Give me back only the  directions, explaining the style, queues and every thing like that.

Give me back only the dialogue and nothing else. The purpose of this is to create a chunked dialogue. So no directions, no explaining the style, no queues or anything like that. Just straight up dialogue to be chunked out. Do not give me a response explaining anything, simple give me the words that are meant to be spoken

IMPORTANT DIALOGUE RULES:
  - DO NOT EXCEED 36 syllables per chunk
  - GIVE EXACTLY 5 chunks with a clear beginning video dialogue that does not trigger a transition for the first chunk and clear ending video dialogue telling the user to download the app for the last chunk
  - Mention the app name vs using a textbook or flashcard style app like DuoLingo at the second chunk  
- Never use phrases that sound like segment beginnings
- Never use phrases that sound like segment endings
- Write as if the speaker is mid-conversation, not starting or ending a lesson
- Avoid instructional/teacher language - sound like a friend sharing, not a teacher lecturing
- No call-to-action phrases within the dialogue (save those for captions/overlays or the last chunk)
- Each sentence should flow naturally into the next without feeling like a "moment" or "beat"

  BAD examples (trigger transitions):
  - "Let's learn a useful phrase"
  - "Repeat it with me"
  - "Now here's the important part"
  - "And that's how you do it"

  GOOD examples (continuous speech):
  - "A useful phrase is..."
  - "Try saying it: ..."
  - "The interesting thing is..."
  - "Which brings us to..."

The purpose is to generate a prompt that won't signal a video transition of any kind as this is a talking head video and we want it to be a single segment.

Make it fun and powerful, don't be shy about being silly or energetic.

Give me back only the dialogue and nothing else. The purpose of this is to create a chunked dialogue for video generation.

  CRITICAL: Avoid any phrases that sound like beginnings or endings of segments. No "Let's learn", "Repeat after me", "That's all for now", etc. Write as continuous mid-conversation speech that flows naturally. Each chunk should feel like it could be in the middle of a longer conversation, never a clear intro or outro.

No directions, no style explanations, no stage queues. Just the spoken words, written to flow continuously without natural "break points" that video AI might interpret as transitions.

This is for a talking head video and we should add that detail.

Describe this image for veo 3.1 fast. Static camera. Single continuous shot. No transitions, no cuts, no scene changes. CRITICAL: The framing must remain exactly the same throughout the entire video. No zooming, no aspect ratio changes, no black borders appearing. The first frame and last frame should have identical composition. Keep the visual clear and without any buttons or phone components. Ensure we include all the details of the person in the image, from their skin texture, any blemishes, their hand movements as they speak and do all of it with them in the view of someone who is doing a video recording on their phone. ensure we include a pause before every sentence. Ensure the video only has natural background noise. Ensure that also the video always ends with the person looking at the camera. Make it fun, give the character energy.

data.outputText:
A high-definition, vertical 9:16 talking head video captured from the perspective of someone holding a smartphone. The camera is completely static for a single, continuous shot with no transitions, no cuts, and no scene changes. The framing remains perfectly locked throughout the entire duration; there is no zooming, no shifting in aspect ratio, and no black borders. The composition of the first frame is identical to the last frame.

The subject is a young woman with long, straight blonde hair tucked behind her ears, sitting at a low wooden table on a traditional Japanese veranda. She has a bright, energetic, and fun personality. The lighting is soft and natural, highlighting her realistic skin texture, including fine pores and subtle natural blemishes. She is wearing a traditional Japanese samue with large geometric blocks of slate blue and beige. 

As she speaks, she is highly animated and expressive, using her hands to gesture enthusiastically. Her movements are fluid and natural. Between every spoken sentence, she takes a deliberate, brief pause, maintaining a cheerful and engaging presence. She is looking directly into the camera lens as if chatting with a friend. 

The foreground features a weathered wooden table holding sheets of calligraphy paper with black ink characters, a bamboo brush resting on a holder, and an ink stone. The background is a lush, vibrant green Japanese moss garden with slender trees and a traditional stone lantern, all softly out of focus to create depth. The audio consists only of her voice and natural background sounds, such as the distant rustle of leaves and birdsong. The video concludes with her looking directly into the camera with a warm, energetic smile.

data.prompt:
give me a prompt to generate an image of a realistic hot blonde girl wearing Japanese attire outside a Japanese temple setting in a lush garden, make it so he is sitting down at a low wooden table with calligraphy items and kanji. Also on the table I want a phone with the screen exactly like the image provided. 

I want all things to look realistic with natural blemishes, and imperfections. The colors and texture should be more dull to better give that real life non ai look. 

This character should look like someone you would listen to on any topic but still appear friendly and inviting.

The character should be oriented towards the camera. The character should always look between 21-25, not to be mistaken for a minor.

Make sure we do not include any camera or phone ui in the photo as if looking through the lense. We want purely a finished photo and we do want the image quality to look like it was taken by an iphone.

The camera should be oriented right infront of the person

Give back only the image generation prompt and nothing else

She is sitting on a cushion at a low, weathered wooden table in a lush, mossy Japanese temple garden. She is wearing a traditional linen yukata in a muted tone. On the table are authentic calligraphy tools, including a bamboo brush, an ink stone, and rice paper with hand-drawn kanji. A smartphone lies flat on the table, its screen brightly displaying a "Choose Character" language learning interface with a list of illustrated avatars including a Shiba Inu named Maru and several anime-style characters. The image quality features natural skin textures, subtle pores, and minor imperfections with a slightly dull, non-vibrant color palette to mimic a real-life mobile snapshot. The lighting is natural daylight with soft, realistic shadows, avoiding any cinematic or AI-polished effects. No camera interface or phone overlays are visible.
